newsitem.title: UK: London gold, silver quiet and consolidating.
newsitem.headline: London gold, silver quiet and consolidating.

text.p: The precious metals market was sleepy and desperately seeking direction in early European trade on Wednesday, dealers said.
"It's dead this morning. Gold is right in the middle of support at $380 and resistance at $382," a dealer said.
Bullion fixed at $380.90 an ounce, barely changed from Tuesday afternoon's $380.85 fixing.
"The only positive sign is that gold is still above $380, which is an important psychological level," an analyst said.
But market sentiment in gold was still mostly bearish after prices slid to 18-month lows last week within a month-old downtrend, dealers said.
"In the medium term, if there is a big price move, it's going to be lower," with $375 as the first target, one said.
The gold market would be watching for September U.S. Producer Price Index data on Friday, analysts said.

But dealers said it was unlikely to affect prices unless the figures had a significant effect on other markets. Investors have been ignoring gold in light of benign U.S. inflation and booming stock and bond market.
Silver was even more somnolent than gold, just one cent lower at $4.89 an ounce. "It doesn't seem that silver or the other metals are trading at all so far," a dealer said.

Platinum was also little changed at $384.25, with little obvious scope to move out of its recent $383-$386 range. "The platinum market is thin and lacklustre," an analyst said. The market was cautious of about platinum because key Japanese demand for the metal was slack and the volume of metal stocks held by important producer Russia was a mystery, he said.
However, platinum was due to for a move up after its recent drops to near 2-1/2 year lows, analysts said.
Palladium was unchanged at $118.25 an ounce and seen vulnerable to downside pressure after drifting below the key $120 support area again earlier this week.
